body:
This is actually a duplicate of #2289, where markdown parsing is getting applied inside tex environments, which it shouldn't.

There are two workarounds for your equation:

whitespace changes to miss the margdown regex:

``` latex
$\mbox{global force }\mathbf{f}_{global}\leftarrow\mathbf{T}^T\leftarrow\mbox{local force }\mathbf{f}\leftarrow\mathbf{K}
    \leftarrow\mbox{local displacement }\mathbf{q}\leftarrow\mathbf{T}\leftarrow\mbox{global displacement }\mathbf{q} _{global}$
```

Or escape the underscores, so markdown doesn't treat them as implying `<em>`

``` latex
$\mbox{global force }\mathbf{f}\_{global}\leftarrow\mathbf{T}^T\leftarrow\mbox{local force }\mathbf{f}\leftarrow\mathbf{K}
    \leftarrow\mbox{local displacement }\mathbf{q}\leftarrow\mathbf{T}\leftarrow\mbox{global displacement }\mathbf{q} \_{global}$
```

I would recommend using the first, because when #2289 is fixed, if you went with the second, you would have to go in and remove all of your escapes for it to draw right again.  Obviously neither is ideal.

Closing as duplicate, please continue any further questions in #2289.

Thanks a lot.

Tomek

On 22 Aug 2012, at 19:15, Min RK wrote:

> Or escape the underscores, so markdown doesn't treat them as

> \leftarrow\mbox{local force }\mathbf{f}\leftarrow\mathbf{K}
>     \leftarrow\mbox{local displacement }\mathbf{q}\leftarrow 
> \mathbf{T}\leftarrow\mbox{global displacement }\mathbf{q} _{global}$
> I would recommend using the first, because when #2289 is fixed, if  
> you went with the second, you would have to go in and remove all of  
> your escapes for it to draw right again. Obviously neither is ideal.
> 
> Closing as duplicate, please continue any further questions in #2289.
>
